Polyhex Application Documentation¶

This documentation provides an overview of the Polyhex application, its class structure, and views.

Content¶

  1. Polyhex Views

  2. Polyhex Main

  3. Polyhex Board

  4. Polyhex Piece

  5. Polyhex Solver

Polyhex Main¶

The Polyhex class handles the core functionality of the application. It includes the logic for solving the Polyhex puzzle and managing the state of the puzzle board.

class polyhex.polyhex.Polyhex_Solver[source]¶

Bases: object

Solver class for the Polyhex puzzle.

This class is responsible for solving the Polyhex puzzle by verifying the board and generating solutions based on the available pieces.

Attributes:

board (list): The current state of the Polyhex puzzle board. pieces_placed (list): A list of pieces that have already been placed on the board.

solve(solutions)[source]¶

Solves the Polyhex puzzle by generating all possible solutions for the current board state.

This method uses the solver.Solver to generate solutions based on the available pieces and board state. It validates the board before generating the solutions and appends them to the provided solutions list.

Args:

solutions (multiprocessing.Manager.list): A shared list to store generated solutions.

Returns:

bool: True if the solutions were successfully generated, False if the board is invalid.

Polyhex Views¶

The views in this module handle the HTTP requests for rendering different parts of the Polyhex application, such as the puzzle board and solution generator.

polyhex.views.get_solution_count(request)[source]¶

Returns the current count of generated solutions.

This view returns the current number of generated solutions, checking if the solution generation process is still active. If the process is complete, a message indicating that the generation is finished is returned.

Args:

request (HttpRequest): The HTTP request object.

Returns:
JsonResponse: A JSON response containing:

  • {“length”: <count>} if the process is active.

  • {“Done”: “Generation completed”} if the process is not running.

polyhex.views.home(request)[source]¶

Displays the homepage for the Polysphere Pyramid application.

This view renders the homepage, where users can start interacting with the Polyhex puzzle.

Args:

request (HttpRequest): The HTTP request object.

Returns:

HttpResponse: The rendered homepage template.

polyhex.views.polyhex_generator(request)[source]¶

Displays the generator page for the Polysphere Pyramid application.

This view renders the generator page where users can generate solutions for the Polyhex puzzle. It also provides the current number of solutions and the number of pieces placed.

Args:

request (HttpRequest): The HTTP request object.

Returns:

HttpResponse: The rendered generator page template.

polyhex.views.polyhex_solutions(request)[source]¶

Handles the solution generation and reset actions for the Polyhex puzzle.

This view processes POST requests for generating solutions, resetting the puzzle state, and saving a new puzzle configuration. Depending on the button pressed, it either renders the solutions page, resets the puzzle, or saves the new puzzle state.

Args:

request (HttpRequest): The HTTP request object containing form data.

Returns:

HttpResponseRedirect: A redirect response to another view, either the solutions page or the puzzle generator.

polyhex.views.puzzle(request)[source]¶

Displays the puzzle page for the Polysphere Pyramid application.

This view renders the puzzle page where users can interact with the current puzzle, viewing the current board state and the number of solutions generated.

Args:

request (HttpRequest): The HTTP request object.

Returns:

HttpResponse: The rendered puzzle page template.

polyhex.views.start_generator(request)[source]¶

Starts the solution generation process.

This view initiates the solution generation process by starting a new process, if one is not already running. It ensures that only one process can be active at a time.

Args:

request (HttpRequest): The HTTP request object.

Returns:
JsonResponse: A JSON response indicating the status of the process:

  • {“status”: “started”} if the process starts successfully.

  • {“status”: “already running”} if the process is already active.

  • {“error”: “Invalid request”} for invalid requests.

polyhex.views.stop_generator(request)[source]¶

Stops the solution generation process if it is currently running.

This view terminates the ongoing solution generation process upon a POST request and ensures the process is stopped properly.

Args:

request (HttpRequest): The HTTP request object, expected to be a POST request.

Returns:
JsonResponse: A JSON response indicating the result of the stop action:

  • {“Success”: “Stopped Successfully”} if the process is terminated successfully.

  • {“error”: “Solver not running”} if no process is active.

  • {“error”: “Invalid request”} for invalid requests.

Polyhex Board¶

This module is responsible for managing the puzzle board structure, including the initialization and manipulation of the board grid. It contains logic for positioning pieces and verifying the validity of piece placements within the puzzle.

class polyhex.solver_functions.board.Board(board=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Represents a 3D board with layers and cells for placing polyhex pieces.

count_cells()[source]¶

Counts the total number of cells in the board.

Returns:

The total number of cells.

Return type:

int

get_matching_empty_regions(region)[source]¶

Finds all regions on the board that match the given region and are free.

Parameters:

region (list[tuple[int, int, int]]) – A list of tuples representing cell coordinates (x, y, z).

Returns:

A list of matching empty regions.

Return type:

list[list[tuple[int, int, int]]]

get_piece_locations()[source]¶

Retrieves the locations of all placed pieces on the board.

Returns:

A dictionary where keys are piece IDs and values are lists of their cell coordinates.

Return type:

dict[int, list[tuple[int, int, int]]]

is_region_free(region)[source]¶

Checks if a given region of cells is free on the board.

Parameters:

region (list[tuple[int, int, int]]) – A list of tuples representing cell coordinates (x, y, z).

Returns:

True if the region is free, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

verify_board()[source]¶

Verifies the validity of the board by checking the placement of all pieces.

Returns:

True if the board is valid, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

Polyhex Piece¶

The module handles the properties and behaviors of individual puzzle pieces. It includes logic for defining piece shapes, positioning, and interactions with the board.

class polyhex.solver_functions.piece.Piece(piece_id, custom_shape=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Represents a polyhex piece with all possible transformations.

polyhex.solver_functions.piece.build_transformations(cells)[source]¶

Generates all unique transformations (rotations, reflections, leans, transposes) of a piece.

Parameters:

cells (list[tuple[int, int, int]]) – The initial list of cell coordinates for the piece.

Returns:

A list of unique transformations.

Return type:

list[list[tuple[int, int, int]]]

polyhex.solver_functions.piece.lean(cell)[source]¶

Transforms a cell to its leaning position.

Parameters:

cell (tuple[int, int, int]) – The cell coordinates to transform.

Returns:

Transformed cell coordinates.

Return type:

tuple[int, int, int]

polyhex.solver_functions.piece.normalize_transformation(cells)[source]¶

Normalizes a set of cell coordinates to their minimum values.

Parameters:

cells (list[tuple[int, int, int]]) – A list of cell coordinates.

Returns:

Normalized cell coordinates.

Return type:

list[tuple[int, int, int]]

polyhex.solver_functions.piece.reflect(cell)[source]¶
Reflects a cell across the xy-plane.

note: our representation of the board is slanted to align layers on x,y 0,0 instead of the center of the pyramid. to account for this, ‘reflecting’ a cell also means shifting it in the -x direction by its y value.

Parameters:

cell (tuple[int, int, int]) – The cell coordinates to reflect.

Returns:

Reflected cell coordinates.

Return type:

tuple[int, int, int]

polyhex.solver_functions.piece.rotate_xy(cell)[source]¶

Rotates a cell around the xy-plane.

Parameters:

cell (tuple[int, int, int]) – The cell coordinates to rotate.

Returns:

Rotated cell coordinates.

Return type:

tuple[int, int, int]

polyhex.solver_functions.piece.transpose_lean_1(cell)[source]¶

Applies the first transposition to a leaned cell.

Parameters:

cell (tuple[int, int, int]) – The cell coordinates to transpose.

Returns:

Transposed cell coordinates.

Return type:

tuple[int, int, int]

polyhex.solver_functions.piece.transpose_lean_2(cell)[source]¶

Applies the second transposition to a leaned cell (not to be used on an already transposed cell).

Parameters:

cell (tuple[int, int, int]) – The cell coordinates to transpose.

Returns:

Transposed cell coordinates.

Return type:

tuple[int, int, int]

polyhex.solver_functions.piece.verify_placement(piece, coords)[source]¶

Verifies whether a given set of coordinates match any transformation of a piece when normalised.

Parameters:

  • piece (Piece) – The Piece object to verify.

  • coords (list[tuple[int, int, int]]) – The cell coordinates to verify.

Returns:

True if the placement is valid, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

polyhex.solver_functions.piece.visualise_piece(coords)[source]¶

Visualises a polyomino piece in 3D space using pyplot. For debugging and testing purposes.

Parameters:

coords (list[tuple[int, int, int]]) – The cell coordinates to visualise.

Polyhex Solver¶

The solver module includes the core algorithm for solving the Polyhex puzzle. It utilizes the board and piece modules to generate valid solutions by testing different piece placements and configurations.

class polyhex.solver_functions.solver.Solver[source]¶

Bases: object

Handles solving polyhex packing problems on the equilateral pyramid board.

cell_to_index = {}¶
generate_board_cell_indexes(hex_board)[source]¶

Generates mappings between board cell coordinates and their matrix column indices.

Parameters:

hex_board (Board) – The hexagonal board to index.

generate_solutions(pieces, hex_board=None)[source]¶

Generates all solutions for the polyhex packing problem.

Parameters:

  • pieces (list[Piece]) – The pieces to place on the board.

  • hex_board (Board, optional) – The board to solve, defaults to an empty board.

Yield:

A list of rows representing a solution matrix

Return type:

generator[list[list[int]]]

id_conversions = {}¶
index_to_cell = {}¶
initialise_packing_matrix(hex_board, pieces)[source]¶

Initializes the matrix for Algorithm X with all possible piece placements.

Parameters:

  • hex_board (Board) – The board to solve. Assumed to be empty.

  • pieces (list[Piece]) – A list of polyomino pieces for the board.

Returns:

The initialized matrix for Algorithm X.

Return type:

algorithm_x_functions.Matrix

initialise_packing_matrix_partial_config(hex_board, remaining_pieces)[source]¶

Initializes the matrix for Algorithm X with a partially configured board.

Parameters:

  • hex_board (Board) – The partially configured board. Assumed to have pieces already placed.

  • remaining_pieces (list[Piece]) – The pieces left for the board.

Returns:

The initialized matrix for Algorithm X.

Return type:

algorithm_x_functions.Matrix

matrix = None¶
rows_to_array_sol(rows, hex_board)[source]¶

Converts a solution matrix to a 3D array representation of the solved board.

Parameters:

  • rows (list[list[int]]) – The rows from the solution matrix.

  • hex_board (Board) – The board used in the solver.

Returns:

A 3D array representation of the solved board.

Return type:

list[list[list[int]]]

solve(pieces, hex_board=None)[source]¶

Solves the polyomino packing problem using Algorithm X.

Parameters:

  • pieces (list[Piece]) – The pieces to place on the board.

  • hex_board (Board, optional) – The board to solve, defaults to an empty board.

Returns:

A list of rows representing a solution matrix, or False if no solution exists.

Return type:

list[list[int]] | bool
